8.text: Sherlock 1:100 000 Map sheet within the Roebourne 1:250 000 map sheet. The project is situated on

9.text: the Sherlock Pastoral Station and is accessed via the unsealed Balla road opposite the Whim Creek

10.text: Hotel and then via 4WD station tracks.

11.text: Spinifex  covered  coastal  flats  with  numerous  small  hills  of  outcropping  Archaean  rocks  in  the

12.text: southern parts characterise the project area.

 5.  Local Geology  
 The  following  descriptions  are  taken  from  The  facies  architecture  of  two  contrasting  volcano-
 sedimentary basin successions from the Archaean Whim Creek Belt, North Pilbara Terrain, Western 
 Australia:  The  intra-continental  arc-related  Whim  Creek  Group  and  plume-related,  continental  rift-
 hosted Bookingarra Group  (Pike, G. 2001, Unpub. Thesis)  
 Pike recognises three lithological associations within the Salt Creek area. These are; Siliclastic and 
 felsic volcanic association, the basalt volcaniclastic association and the felsic igneous association.  
 5.1  Siliclastic and felsic volcanic association  
 Quartz-rich sandstone and granulstone facies  
 Coarse sandstone and granule beds of the quartz-rich sandstone and granulestone facies are 
 interbeded with, and underlie the chloritic quartz-rich sandstone facies. The facies may contain 
 up to 10% <3mm spherical, sub angular quartz grains within a quartz dominated, poorly sorted

29.text: green/grey  chlorite  that  appears  to  replace  mafic  lithic  grains  and  the  facies  thus  comprises

30.text: (mafic)  lithic  arenite.  Feldspathic  grains  (20%)  are  white  and  typically  have  diffuse  margins.

31.text: Quartz  is  a  minor  component  and  forms  less  than  10%  of  the  facies.  The  facies  is  spatially

32.text: associated with the quartz-rich sandstone  and granulstone facies and appears to become more

33.text: quartz-rich  and less chloritic upwards. The source was most likely mafic-dominated with lesser

4.text: Fine-grained units such as the cleaved mudstone facies are preferentially preserved and form

5.text: the  highest  outcrop.  The  facies  is  highly  deformed  and  preserves  two  strong  cleavages  that

6.text: result in a strong rodding fabric. Outcrop may be subdivided into 5-20mm silicious zones that

7.text: are  lensoidal  in  shape  and  more  abundant  (70%)  clay  or  mica-rich,  foliated  material.  The

8.text: silicious  lenses  are  light  blue  to  dark  green-blue  in  colour,  depending  on  the  abundance  of

9.text: chlorite.  The  clay-rich  foliated  material  is  brown  when  weathered  but  purple  along  cleavage,

 the  highest  outcrop.  The  facies  is  highly  deformed  and  preserves  two  strong  cleavages  that 
 result in a strong rodding fabric. Outcrop may be subdivided into 5-20mm silicious zones that 
 are  lensoidal  in  shape  and  more  abundant  (70%)  clay  or  mica-rich,  foliated  material.  The 
 silicious  lenses  are  light  blue  to  dark  green-blue  in  colour,  depending  on  the  abundance  of 
 chlorite.  The  clay-rich  foliated  material  is  brown  when  weathered  but  purple  along  cleavage,

11.text: originally contained some fine sand or silt material.

12.text: This  facies  represents  a  deformed  mudstone  with  interbeds  of  silt  or  fine  sand.  No  other

13.text: structures are preserved within the facies.

15.text: Cleaved siliciclastic and volcanic breccia facies

16.text: Commonly,  the  cleaved  mudstone  facies  passes  upwards  into  a  breccia  with  abundant  dark

17.text: clasts.  This breccia  defines  the  cleaved  siliciclastic  and  volcanic  breccia  facies.  The  matrix  is

18.text: similar  to  the  cleaved  mudstone  facies  and  the  clasts  are  typically  flattened  and  strongly

19.text: elongate  in  one  direction  to  around  10cm,  however  clasts  are  rarely  greater  than  5  mm  in

20.text: thickness, suggesting either originally elongate clasts or, more likely, high strain. The clasts are

21.text: dark  brown and  may contain  abundant  hematite.  No  internal  structure is  noted  except  for  the

22.text: development of a strong cleavage and rare, feldspathic zones, both of which are attributed to

24.text: The  eastern  areas  of  Salt  Creek  host  a  pebble-to  cobble  breccia  that  contains  a  matrix  of

25.text: coarse, quartz rich sand grains similar to those of the quartz-rich sandstone and granulestone

26.text: facies. However within these coarser rocks, the deformation is considerably lower.

28.text: To the east of the above facies is abundant basaltic breccia of the angular basalt breccia facies.

29.text: The facies contains pebble-to-cobble sized clasts that are very angular and show little evidence

30.text: of  transport.  They  are  the  same  clasts  as  described  in  the  cleaved  siliciclastic  and  volcanic

text:
5.2  Basalt volcaniclastic association  
 Cleaved siliciclastic and volcanic breccia facies  
 Commonly,  the  cleaved  mudstone  facies  passes  upwards  into  a  breccia  with  abundant  dark 
 clasts.  This breccia  defines  the  cleaved  siliciclastic  and  volcanic  breccia  facies.  The  matrix  is 
 similar  to  the  cleaved  mudstone  facies  and  the  clasts  are  typically  flattened  and  strongly 
 elongate  in  one  direction  to  around  10cm,  however  clasts  are  rarely  greater  than  5  mm  in 
 thickness, suggesting either originally elongate clasts or, more likely, high strain. The clasts are 
 dark  brown and  may contain  abundant  hematite.  No  internal  structure is  noted  except  for  the 
 development of a strong cleavage and rare, feldspathic zones, both of which are attributed to 
 The  eastern  areas  of  Salt  Creek  host  a  pebble-to  cobble  breccia  that  contains  a  matrix  of 
 coarse, quartz rich sand grains similar to those of the quartz-rich sandstone and granulestone 
 facies. However within these coarser rocks, the deformation is considerably lower.  
 Angular basalt breccia facies  
 To the east of the above facies is abundant basaltic breccia of the angular basalt breccia facies. 
 The facies contains pebble-to-cobble sized clasts that are very angular and show little evidence 
 of  transport.  They  are  the  same  clasts  as  described  in  the  cleaved  siliciclastic  and  volcanic

14.text: Reverse  Circulation  and  Diamond  drilling  has  been  undertaken  in  and  around  the  Salt  Creek

15.text: resource.  A  down  hole  EM  survey  was  completed.  A  wireframe  of  the  resource  at  Salt  Creek  was

16.text: created, but due to the sparse nature of the drilling, a resource model was not created.

18.text: Reverse circulation (RC) drilling was completed at the Salt Creek deposit by Mt Magnet Drilling.

19.text: A  total  of  1  RC  hole  was  drilled  for  60  metres.  A  total  of  15  spear  samples  were  collected.

20.text: Samples  were  either  collected  as  4m  composite  spear  samples  where  there  was  no  visible

text:
Reverse  Circulation  and  Diamond  drilling  has  been  undertaken  in  and  around  the  Salt  Creek 
 resource.  A  down  hole  EM  survey  was  completed.  A  wireframe  of  the  resource  at  Salt  Creek  was 
 created, but due to the sparse nature of the drilling, a resource model was not created.   
 7.1  Reverse Circulation Drilling  
 Reverse circulation (RC) drilling was completed at the Salt Creek deposit by Mt Magnet Drilling. 
 A  total  of  1  RC  hole  was  drilled  for  60  metres.  A  total  of  15  spear  samples  were  collected. 
 Samples  were  either  collected  as  4m  composite  spear  samples  where  there  was  no  visible

5.text: boreholes.  Appropriate B-field surface and downhole probes (only developed in the last 5 yrs)

6.text: are  utilized  to  measure  the  magnetic  fields  directly.  The  transmitter  loop  or  dipole  is

7.text: located/orientated  to  maximize  current  channeling  in  the  target  (i.e.  electrodes  are  along  and

8.text: parallel  to  target  strike).  The  dipole  wire  is  kept  well  away  from  the  specific  survey  area  to

9.text: minimize  the  wire  field  in  the  resulting  measurements.  For  this  reason  the  dipole  wire  is

13.text: The main benefit of the MMR method is it s ability to detect low conductivity targets with respect

14.text: to the surrounding host rocks. The method merely requires a target with a conductivity contrast,

15.text: rather  than  one  with  an  absolute  high  conductivity:  e.g.,  a  300ohm-m  target  in  a  1000ohm-m

 to the surrounding host rocks. The method merely requires a target with a conductivity contrast, 
 rather  than  one  with  an  absolute  high  conductivity:  e.g.,  a  300ohm-m  target  in  a  1000ohm-m

1.text: The search radius of MMR can be far greater than other methods (i.e. DHTEM). For a wire like

4.text: In the past drawbacks to the method have been the need for more demanding instrumentation,

5.text: lower signal to noise ratios and more complex data reduction to strip away the magnetic fields

6.text: due to the wire and current flow within a structured earth. However nowadays with the routine

7.text: use of modern, low-noise B-field surface and downhole sensors, modern receiving instruments

8.text: (i.e. SMARTem receiver) and vastly more computing power for processing the handling of such

text:
The search radius of MMR can be far greater than other methods (i.e. DHTEM). For a wire like 
 In the past drawbacks to the method have been the need for more demanding instrumentation, 
 lower signal to noise ratios and more complex data reduction to strip away the magnetic fields 
 due to the wire and current flow within a structured earth. However nowadays with the routine 
 use of modern, low-noise B-field surface and downhole sensors, modern receiving instruments 
 (i.e. SMARTem receiver) and vastly more computing power for processing the handling of such 
 data is relatively straight forward.
